title: graph theory - Notation for induced subgraphs
body: For a graph $G=(V,E)$ , is there a standard notation for the induced subgraph on $V \setminus \{v,w\}$ where $v,w$ are the endpoints of some edge $e$ ? I know $G[V \setminus \{v,w\}]$ is an option, but I’m looking for something more compact. $G \setminus e$ is used for deletion and $G/e$ is used for contraction, so I’m inclined to use $G-e$ , but perhaps that already has another meaning. graph-theory notation Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jun 28, 2020 at 23:00 James Propp 20.2k 5 5 gold badges 58 58 silver badges 147 147 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 1 $\begingroup$ Isn't $G-e$ used for the spanning subgraph where only the edge is deleted and the vertices remain? How about $G-u-v$? $\endgroup$ bof –  bof 2020-06-28 23:15:24 +00:00 Commented Jun 28, 2020 at 23:15 1 $\begingroup$ Once I used $G-[e]$; page 38 here: arxiv.org/abs/1812.06627 $\endgroup$ Anton Petrunin –  Anton Petrunin 2020-06-28 23:16:22 +00:00 Commented Jun 28, 2020 at 23:16 1 $\begingroup$ As bof said, definitely do not used $G-e$ as that is extremely widespread as meaning that only the edge is removed and not its end-vertices. $\endgroup$ Brendan McKay –  Brendan McKay 2020-06-29 04:40:32 +00:00 Commented Jun 29, 2020 at 4:40 $\begingroup$ I myself would probably use $G-\{v,w\}$ as I always avoid revealing the implementation of my edges as sets, that is, I never state that $e=\{v,w\}$. And then $G-S$ is equally well defined for any set $S$ of vertices. $\endgroup$ M. Winter –  M.
